creator: siffemoz

content:
Do some checks:

Firewall: Access Firewall - it might be the defaulton computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program.

VPN: Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use). Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. Confirm VPN is switched off

Password: Logon to webmail account via a browser to see emails. If this works then you know the password is correct.

In Thunderbird Account Hub Not sure what version of Thunderbird you are using but if up to date then check to see if Account Hub is disabled.

  • Settings > General
  • For 'Account Hub'
  • uncheck/do not select: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'

Check the previously saved passwords for the email address - both incoming and outgoing are removed.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • There should be two lines for the email address - select them and click on 'Remove'
  • click on 'Close'

Then create account.

  • Menu app icon > New Account > Email
  • Enter Name, email address, password and select checkbox to remember password.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird attempts to locate server settings. It knows most but not all. By default, it usually looks for imap, so if you want pop protocol then you will need to reselect it. If it does not locate correct server settings - click on 'Configure Manually'

IMAP Server Settings:

  • Server name: mail.gilanet.com
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

POP Server Settings:

  • Server name: mail.gilanet.com
  • Port: 995
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

SMTP Server Settings:

  • Server name: smtp.gilanet.com
  • If you use Port 465
  • Then use Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • If you use Port: 587
  • then use Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Maybe proxy? Go to TB menu > Settings and search for proxy. Click the 'Settings' button under 'Connection'. Try switching to System or No. If it still doesn't work, ssee if anything relevant shows up in the Error Console:

- press Ctrl-Shift-J

- click the Trash can on the upper left to clear the console

- make sure 'Errors' is the only category selected

- click the 'Get Messages' (cloud) icon at the top of the Folder column

- if there are errors, R. click > Copy Message or Copy all Messages > paste here
creator: siffemoz

content: In your French Thunderbird version go to Affichage > Dossiers and check ✔︎ En-tête du panneau des dossiers I agree with you that this settings is well hidden and it took me while to remember...
creator: Mapenzi

content: you can export an addressbook, but (to my knowledge) not a distribution list. you can import the full addressbook with tools>import>import from a file and follow the links for addressbook. when you get to last menu, it will offer several addressbook formats to import. To know which one to use, check the profile of old laptop's thunderbird. if there is an abook.sqlite file, then on new computer, import the abook.sqlite file. If not, then import the abook.mab file (which is the older version)..
creator: davidsk

content: It may be that thunderbird created a new profile during the update. try clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles and click 'about:profiles' and on next screen you can click to browse other profiles. look in imapmail folder for IMAP account or mail folder for POP account. if you see that info in an inactive profile, that may be the one you want. click the launch button to verify. if it works, and if your account logs in, that would indicate that thunderbird had retained the password. You can retrieve it at settings>privacy&security
creator: davidsk
